situation: Helper puts tray on Mr.H.�s table & opens milk container. Mr.H. eats w/o further assistance. Helper removes the tray once Mr.H. is done eating. Mr. H. does not have feeding tube.
rationale: Helper opens Mr.H.�s milk container.  This is setup assistance.  Delivery & pick up of trays is not considered in scoring Eating.

situation: MrsV. has had difficulty seeing on her left side since her stroke. At meals, helper reminds her to scan entire tray ensureing she has seen all food items. She does not get any physical helper assistance. Mrs.V. does not have feeding tube.
rationale: Helper provides verbal cues so patient sees & eats all her food.

situation: Mrs.Y. is home care patient. Her intake is limited to foods like applesauce, yogurt & pureed meats.  She feeds self after husband opens containers. About half her calories & fluid needs are received from PEG feedings. She administers her feedings after her husband brings her supplies & opens the containers. He also removes empty containers & cleans supplies.
rationale: Mrs.H. does not have dietary restrictions, but sometimes needs 2-3 swallows so food clears throat due to difficulty w/ pharyngeal peristalsis. She requires verbal cues to use the compensatory strategy/ extra swallows to clear food.

situation: Mrs.H. does not have dietary restrictions, but sometimes needs 2-3 swallows so the food clears throat due to difficulty w/ pharyngeal peristalsis. She requires verbal cues to use the compensatory strategy/ extra swallows to clear food.
rationale: Mrs.H. swallows all types of food consistencies, but requires verbal cueing from helper.

situation: Mrs.F. brushes her teeth while sitting on the side of bed. Helper gathers t-brush, t-paste, water & empty cup & puts them on bedside table for her.  Once Mrs.F. finishes brushing teeth, which she does w/o any help, helper returns to gather her items & dispose waste.
rationale: Helper provides setup/ clean-up assistance. The patient brushes teeth w/o any help.

situation: Mr.S. brushes teeth at sink in the bathroom. Helper provides steadying assistance to Mr. S. as he walks to bathroom. Helper applies t-paste onto t-brush.  Once done w/ oral hygiene & washing his hands/ face, helper provides steadying assistance as patient walks back to bed.
rationale: Helper provides setup assistance (putting t-paste on the t-brush) so that Mr.S. can brush his teeth. Do not consider assistance provided to get to or from the bathroom to score Oral Hygiene.

situation: Mr.W. begins to brush his teeth after helper applies t-paste onto t-brush. He brushes his top front teeth, but cannot finish due to fatigue. Helper completes the activity by brushing back-upper teeth & all lower-teeth.
rationale: Patient begins activity. Helper completes activity by performing >50% of the effort.

situation: Mrs.R. transfers onto toilet & pulls down her underwear & pants as helper provides moderate assistance. After voiding, she cleanses self. She then stands up & pulls up underwear & pants as helper steadies her.
rationale: Helper provides steadying assistance as patient performs toilet hygiene tasks. The assistance provided to Mrs.R as she gets onto & off toilet is not considered for the Toilet Hygiene Item. It would be scored under Toilet Transfer.

situation: Mrs.L. uses toilet to void & have bowel movements. A helper walks into bathroom w/ her in case she needs help w/ transferring or adjusting clothing.  During the last 2 days, Helper has been present in the bathroom, but has not provided any physical assistance w/ managing clothes or cleansing.
rationale: Helper provides supervision as patient performs toilet hygiene tasks.

situation: Mrs.P. has urinary urgency. As soon as she gets in bathroom, she asks assistant to lift her gown & pull down her underwear. After voiding, Mrs.P. wipes self & pulls her underwear back up.
rationale: Helper provides more than touching assistance. But patient does 2 the 3 toilet hygiene tasks.  Therefore patient does more than half the effort & Helper does less than half the effort.

situation: Mr.D. has a catheter, but needs to use the toilet to have a bowel movement. He can ambulate into bathroom on his own & sit down on the commode.  He requires a helper to hang catheter appropriately on the cabinet next to toilet.  When he is through he lets helper know, & helper hands him toilet paper for him to wipe self.
rationale: Patient needs helper for initial preparation to hang Foley bag appropriately while he is sitting on toilet.  Patient then needs helper to hand him toilet paper afterwards to prevent him from having to reach.  The patient performs activity of toilet hygiene independently.

situation: Mrs.Z. wears a bra & a sweatshirt most days in rehabilitation program. Mrs.Z threads her arms through the bra straps & helper hooks the bra. Mrs.Z. puts her sweatshirt on w/o any assistance.
rationale: Helper provides assistance w/ UB dressing, but patient performs more than half the effort.

situation: Mr.B dresses his UB independently once his sweatshirt is placed next to him on his bed.
rationale: The patient dresses self once helper provides setup assistance.

situation: Mr.X sits on side of bed to dress his UB.  He is able to thread his arms through sleeves of his button-down shirt, but requires steadying as he leans to his left side to insure he does not fall over.
rationale: The patient can dress his UB, but requires occasional touching to steady him as he leans to his weak side for safety reasons.

situation: Mrs.Z. requires supervision when standing to pull up her underpants & pants due to balance problems.
rationale: Helper does not provide any physical assistance but is required to supervise patient due to safety concerns.

situation: Mr.B is unable to thread his pants or underpants on his feet due to hip precautions. Once Helper begins to thread pants & underpants, Mr.B pulls them up to knees, stands & pulls them up around hips & zips pants. Helper puts on socks & shoes.
rationale: Helper performs physical assist but for less than half the tasks of LB dressing.  This item does not address putting on footwear - that assistance will be coded in another item.

situation: Mr.Z is unable to remove his pants/ underpants independently. Once lying down in the bed, he can unfasten pants.  He can roll slightly to his right & left & assist helper to pull pants over his hips.  He can lift each leg one at a time so helper can remove pants & underpants.
rationale: Helper performs physical assist for more than half the tasks of LB dressing.  Patient does participate some in the task by unfastening pants & assisting w/ pulling pants down over his hips.

situation: After helper places the wash basin filled w/ water, soap, a washcloth & towel on the bedside table, Mrs.L. washes, rinses, & dries her UB. She asks helper to wash, rinse & dry her back only. Helper also removes all the items once Mrs.L. is done.
rationale: Helper provides setup assistance. Assistance w/ washing the back is not considered when rating this item.

situation: Mrs.M. is assisted to a shower chair & requires assistance of one to support her sitting up.  Helper prepares the water & a washcloth & hands it to Mrs.M instructing her to wash her face.  While helper washes & rinses the rest of her UB, Mrs.M washes one side of her face w/ her washcloth, but helper finishes it & dries her off.
rationale: Mrs.M participated in the activity, but helper provided > 50% the effort to complete washing her UB.

situation: Mrs.O. is recovering from pneumonia.  After Helper places the wash basin filled w/ water, soap, a washcloth & a towel on the bedside table, Mrs.O. washes & rinses her UB.  She is too fatigued to dry self completely & helper notices her oxygen saturation levels are at 86% after she finishes rinsing self.  Helper dries her off & removes all the items.
rationale: Mrs.O was able to complete two the three activities in washing her UB, but could not completely dry self, requiring Helper to provide less than half the effort in the task.

situation: Mr.B. pushes up on the bed to get self from a lying to a seated position. Helper provides steadying assistance as Mr.B. scoots self to the edge the bed & lowers feet to floor.
rationale: Helper provides touching assistance as patient moves from a lying to sitting position.

situation: As Mr.M. gets from a sitting to standing position, helper touches his arm to steady him.
rationale: Helper provides touching assistance only.

situation: Mr.L. had a stroke 3 days ago & uses a WC for mobility. When Mr.L. gets out of bed, helper moves the WC into correct position, & locks the brakes so that Mr.L. can transfer into WC safely. Mr.L. transfers into WC by self (no helper) about 10 minutes later.
rationale: Helper provides setup assistance. Mr.L. does not need help during the transfer.

situation: Mrs.Y. is anxious about getting up to use the bathroom. She asks helperto stay w/her in the bathroom as she gets on & off the toilet. The helper stays w/her, as requested, & provides verbal encouragement to Mrs.Y.
rationale: Helper provides supervision/verbal cues as Mrs.Y. transfers onto & off the toilet.

situation: Mrs.L. is unable to bear her full weight on her left leg. As she walks 60 feet down the hall w/her crutches, her husband supports her trunk. He provides <50% of the effort.
rationale: The helper, her husband,  provides trunk support as the patient walks >50 feet, but not >100 feet.

situation: Mrs. M. is unable to bear any weight on her right leg. After the helper provides steadying assistance to transfer from the bed into the wheelchair, Mrs. M. propels herself about 120 feet down the hall using her left leg.
rationale: The patient wheels herself more than 100 feet, but less than 150 feet. The assistance provided by the helper w/the transfer is not considered when scoring longest distance wheeled. There is a separate item for scoring bed to chair transfers.

situation: Mr.J. sits on a tub bench as he washes, rinses & dries self. Helper stays w/him to ensure safety & provides lifting assistance as he gets onto/off the tub bench.
rationale: Helper provides supervision as Mr.J. washes, rinses, & dries self in the tub.

situation: Mr. W. is receiving rehab after a left hemisphere stroke w/subsequent right sided weakness.  He presents lying in bed supine when the therapist meets him to evaluate.  The therapist instructs him to reach for the right bedrail w/his left arm & pull himself over.  The patient does not respond but once the therapist places his left hand on the bedrail & gives him visual cues, the patient responds & begins to pull himself over.  He requires assistance from the therapist to reach full sidelying.  The patient does not let go of the bedrail, however, & requires assistance from the therapist to get back on his back.  His right arm is flaccid & therefore the patient is unable to grasp the bedrail to roll to his left.
rationale: A helper is needed to complete the task of rolling to each side & back to supine.  The patient does initiate some part of rolling to his right side, however, & therefore is not coded as '1: Dependent'

situation: Mrs. H. requires assistance from a helper to transfer from sitting at the edge of the bed to lying in bed due to paralysis on her right side. Mrs. H can use the bedrail to lower herself down to the bed, but cannot lift her legs completely up onto the bed.  The helper lifts Mrs. H's legs & assists her in positioning them. Mrs. H then uses her arms & upper body to position her trunk.
rationale: A helper is needed to transfer from a seated to a lying position, but Mrs. H. does a majority of the task.

situation: Mr. T bends over from a standing position to reach for his shaver. The patient care technician places both hands lightly on his waist to steady him as she observed his unsteadiness in performing the task.
rationale: The helper provides steadying assistance to Mr. T to prevent him from falling.

situation: Mrs.K. sits on the side bed. Helper puts her slipper over her forefoot & then instructs Mrs.K to pull the slipper over her heel.  Mrs.K is able to do this, the process is repeated on the other foot.  Mrs.K is able to get slippers off her feet w/o assistance.
rationale: The patient requires assistance from helper to start task, but once the slipper is started, patient can complete task.

situation: Mrs. P. has orders for touch-down weight-bearing on her right leg.  She struggles w/keeping her weight bearing precautions on even surfaces, but is able to walk 5 feet w/substantial/maximal assistance & a rolling walker.  She approaches a single step, but is visibly concerned about attempting to go up or down one step.
rationale: The therapist can infer from the patient's level of performance w/walking on even surfaces that she is dependent for a single step due to her difficulty in maintaining her weight-bearing orders on even surfaces.  This would be the most appropriate score, rather than a 'S: Not Attempted due to Safety Concerns', 'N: Not Applicable', or 'P: Patient Refused'.

situation: Mrs. F. is able to stand w/maximal assistance from the helper.  Once standing on her walker, she is able to walk 10 feet w/< 50% assistance from the helper.
rationale: The patient is able to ambulate, but is unable to walk 50 feet & make two turns

situation: Mrs. A. has orders for partial-weight-bearing on her right leg.  She has 12 steps to get to the 2nd level of her home where her bedroom is. She is able to go up the 12 steps w/two handrails w/partial assistance from the helper.  At the top of the stairs, she has trouble maintaining her partial weight- bearing status while turning around & requires maximal assistance from the helper to keep her balance.  When coming down the stairs, she is fatigued & is unable to get down w/o > 50% assistance from the helper.
rationale: The patient is able to get up the steps w/< 50% assistance from the helper but is unable to  turn around & get back down the steps w/o > 50% assistance from the helper.

situation: Mrs. B. has orders for 50% weight-bearing on her right leg.  She has five steps to get into her home. She wears 2 liters of oxygen at all times & has orders to keep her oxygen saturation above 90%.  Using two handrails, she is able to go up two steps w/substantial assistance from the helper.  After two steps, her oxygen saturation drops to 86%.  The helper waits 30 sec & it does not come back up.  Mrs. B begins to get anxious that she is not going to be able to get down.  The helper abandons trying to go up any more steps & assists Mrs. B down the steps w/substantial/maximum assistance.
rationale: The therapist decides not to pursue completing the task for medical reasons. The patient's oxygen saturation was less than acceptable & she was becoming more anxious which would only increase her work of breathing.  She was unable to go up/down four steps, & while part of this was related to her medical condition, '1' is the most appropriate score.

situation: Mr. K. has a driveway at home w/an uneven surface. The physical therapist has been working on ambulation w/him outside of the facility to prepare him for this task. Mr. K. had a hip replacement & is now using a small based quad cane w/which to walk indoors. Upon walking outside on the uneven surface he requires steadying assistance as he tends to be unsteady while using his device on this surface.
rationale: Patient requires steadying (touching) assistance in order to perform the activity safely.

situation: Mr. Y. can lower himself into the passenger seat of his son's car & swing his legs into the car.  When getting out of the car, he swings his legs out on his own.  He needs some physical assistance from the helper to initiate standing up due to the height of the car set.
rationale: The patient is able to stoop, bend or turn to get in the car w/o physical assistance, & once the patient is sitting in the car seat, he is able to swing his legs into & out of the car.  He is unable to stand up on his own & the helper provides < 50% of the effort.
